description: The adjective is from tutor (noun) +‎ -ial, ultimately from Latin tūtor (“watcher, protector, defender”). The noun is transferred from the adjective.

entries.meaning: Of or pertaining to a tutor; belonging to, or exercised by, a tutor.
examples: The probability is that any verse of this nature, in which the lines are worn smooth, is one which has been causing tutorial ears to tingle for a generation at least; and very probably it is known in a variety of forms.

entries.meaning: A self-paced learning exercise; a lesson prepared so that a student can learn at their own speed, at their convenience.
An interactive class taught by a tutor to students at university or college, individually or in small groups.
(computing) A video or text that is basically a how-to (advice or instruction on a particular topic)
